benchmark_details.name: MedPAIR (Medical Dataset Comparing Physicians and AI Relevance Estimation and Question Answering)
benchmark_details.overview: MedPAIR is a dataset designed to evaluate how physician trainees and large language models prioritize relevant information when answering medical question-answering (QA) questions. It includes 1,300 QA pairs with sentence-level relevance annotations from 36 physician trainees, allowing comparison between human and model relevance assessments.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To establish a rigorous pre-reasoning evaluation by quantifying sentence-level relevance alignment between LLMs and physician trainees in medical QA tasks.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The dataset is limited to the medical domain and requires expert labels for relevance, which may not be feasible for all clinical scenarios.

data.source: The data is sourced from four existing QA benchmark datasets: MMLU (Precision Medicine), JAMA Clinical Challenge, MedBullets, and MedXpertQA, with additional annotations from physician trainees.
data.annotation: Annotations were performed by 36 physician trainees who labeled each sentence as 'High Relevance', 'Low Relevance', or 'Irrelevant'.

methodology.calculation: Calculating sentence relevance labels through majority voting among annotators and assessing model performance before and after pruning contexts based on relevance.
methodology.interpretation: Performance is measured by the degree of accuracy improvements when irrelevant and low-relevance context is removed based on human annotations.
methodology.baseline_results: The baseline accuracy for LLMs before filtering contextual information ranged from 30% to 95.6%, with significant improvements observed after applying relevance filtering.
methodology.validation: Validation was conducted through comparison of annotated relevance with model-assigned relevance labels.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: Analysis includes the breakdown of participants by demographics, providing insights into the expertise level of the annotators.
harm: Potential disparities in model performance across different demographic groups.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: The dataset is publicly available under an open access license, details of which are provided alongside resource links.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: Consent was obtained from all human annotators involved in the study.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: The study received IRB approval (IRB2411001474) exempting it from further review based on specified criteria.
